Al-Hussein bin Saeed from Hammad from Hurayz (1) from Muhammad bin Muslim from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a dog drinking from a vessel, he said: "Wash the vessel." And about a cat, he said: "There is no harm in performing ablution with what it leaves behind, for it is only of the predators."
40 - 2 And with this chain of narration from Hammad from Hurayz from Al-Fadl Abi Al-Abbas who said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about what is left over from a cat, a sheep, a cow, a camel, a donkey, a horse, mules, wild animals and predators. I did not leave anything without asking him about it. He said: "There is nothing wrong with it," until I reached the dog, then he said: "It is impure and filthy. Do not perform ablution with what it leaves behind, pour out that water and wash it with soil the first time, then with water."
41 - 3 And the Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, informed me from Abu Al-Qasim Jaafar bin Muhammad bin Qulawayh from his father from Saad bin Abdullah from Ahmad bin Muhammad from Ayyub bin Nuh from Safwan from Muawiyah bin Shurayh who said: 'Uzafir asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, while I was with him, about the leftovers of a cat, a sheep, a cow, a camel, a donkey, a horse, mules and predators, whether one can drink from it or perform ablution with it. He said: "Yes, drink from it and perform ablution." He said: I said to him, "The dog?" He said: "No." I said: "Is it not a predator?" He said: "No, by God, it is impure.
No, by God, it is impure."
42 - 4 Saad bin Abdullah (2) from Ahmad bin Al-Hassan bin Ali bin Faddal from Abdullah bin Bukayr from Muawiyah bin Maysarah from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, something similar to it.
43 - 5 As for what Al-Hussein bin Saeed narrated from Ibn Sinan from Ibn Muskan from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about performing ablution with what a dog licks, or a cat licks, or a camel or an animal or other than that drinks from, can one perform ablution or take a bath with it? He said: "Yes, unless you find other than it, then avoid it out of piety." This narration does not contradict the earlier narrations, because the interpretation of this narration is that we understand it to mean if the water is a kurr or more than that. 44 - 6 اخبرني به الشيخ رحمه الله عن أبي القاسم جعفر بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن أبي جعفر أحمد بن محمد عن عثمان بن عيسى عن سماعة بن مهران عن أبي بصير عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: ليس بفضل السنور بأس أن يتوضأ منه ويشرب منه ولا يشرب (1) من سؤر الكلب إلا أن يكون حوضا كبيرا يستقى منه.
45 - 7 وبهذا الاسناد عن أحمد بن محمد عن علي بن الحكم عن أبي أيوب الخزاز عن محمد بن مسلم قال: سألته عن الماء تبول فيه الدواب وتلغ فيه الكلاب ويغتسل فيه الجنب قال إذا كان قدر كر لم ينجسه شئ.
10 - باب الماء القليل يحصل فيه شئ من النجاسة 46 - 1 اخبرني أبو الحسين بن أبي جيد القمي عن محمد بن الحسن بن الوليد عن الصفار عن أحمد بن محمد والحسين بن الحسن بن ابان عن الحسين بن سعيد عن ابن سنان عن ابن مسكان عن أبي بصير عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: سألته عن الجنب يجعل الركوة (2) أو التور (3) فيدخل إصبعه فيه قال: ان كانت يده قذرة فاهرقه، وإن كان لم يصبها قذر فليغتسل منه هذا مما قال الله تعالى (ما جعل عليكم في الدين من حرج). 47 - 2 - وبهذا الاسناد عن الحسين بن سعيد عن أخيه الحسن عن زرعة عن سماعة (ابن مهران) (4) عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: إذا أصابت الرجل جنابة فأدخل يده في الاناء فلا بأس إن لم يكن أصاب يده شئ من المني.

44 - 6 The Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, told me from Abu al-Qasim Ja'far ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Sa'd ibn Abdullah, from Abu Ja'far Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from Uthman ibn Isa, from Sama'ah ibn Mehran, from Abu Basir, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "There is nothing wrong with what is left over by a cat, it is okay to perform ablution with it and drink from it. But one should not drink (1) from what is left over by a dog unless it is a large basin from which water is drawn."
45 - 7 And with this chain of narration, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Abu Ayyub al-Khazzaz, from Muhammad ibn Muslim, who said: "I asked him about water in which animals urinate, dogs lap, and a person in a state of ritual impurity bathes." He said: "If it is the amount of *kurr*, nothing makes it impure."
10 - Chapter on a small amount of water that becomes impure.
46 - 1 Abu al-Hussein ibn Abi Jayyid al-Qummi told me from Muhammad ibn al-Hasan ibn al-Walid, from al-Saffar, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad and al-Hussein ibn al-Hasan ibn Aban, from al-Hussein ibn Saeed, from Ibn Sinan, from Ibn Muskan, from Abu Basir, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "I asked him about a person in a state of ritual impurity who puts the small skin container (2) or the tub (3) [of water] and puts his finger in it." He said: "If his hand is dirty, then pour it out, but if it is not affected by dirt, then he should perform ablution with it. This is from what God Almighty said: 'He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty.'"
47 - 2 - And with this chain of narration, from al-Hussein ibn Saeed, from his brother al-Hasan, from Zur'ah, from Sama'ah (ibn Mehran) (4), from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "If a person is affected by *janabah* and puts his hand in the vessel, then there is nothing wrong with it if his hand has not been affected by any semen."

48 - 3 وأخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أبي القاسم جعفر بن محمد عن محمد بن يعقوب عن محمد بن يحيى عن أحمد بن محمد عن عثمان بن عيسى عن سماعة قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن جرة وجد فيها خنفساء قد مات قال: القه وتوضأ منه وإن كان عقربا فاهرق الماء وتوضأ من ماء غيره، وعن رجل معه إناءان فيهما ماء وقع في أحدهما قذر لا يدري أيهما هو وليس يقدر على ماء غيره قال: يهريقهما ويتيمم.
49 - 4 محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن العمركي عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى بن جعفر عليه السلام قال: سألته عن الدجاجة والحمامة وأشباههما تطأ العذرة ثم تدخل في الماء يتوضأ منه للصلاة قال: لا إلا أن يكون الماء كثيرا قدر كر من ماء.
50 - 5 فاما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن القاسم بن محمد عن علي بن أبي حمزة قال:
سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام (عن الماء الساكن (1) يكون فيه الجيفة أيصلح الاستنجاء منه (2) فقال) توضأ من الجانب الآخر ولا تتوضأ من جانب الجيفة.
51 - 6 عنه عن عثمان بن عيسى عن سماعة قال: سألته عن الرجل يمر بالميتة في الماء فقال (3) يتوضأ من الناحية التي ليس فيها الميتة 52 - 7 وعنه عن القاسم بن محمد عن أبان عن زكار بن فرقد عن عثمان بن زياد قال:
قلت لأبي جعفر عليه السلام أكون في السفر فاتي الماء النقيع ويدي قذرة فاغمسها في الماء فقال: لا باس.

48 - 3 And the Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, narrated to me from Abu al-Qasim Ja'far bin Muhammad, from Muhammad bin Ya'qub, from Muhammad bin Yahya, from Ahmad bin Muhammad, from Uthman bin Isa, from Sama'a who said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a jar in which a beetle was found dead. He said: "Throw it away and perform ablution with it. But if it is a scorpion, then spill the water and perform ablution with other water." And about a man who has two vessels of water, and filth falls into one of them, and he does not know which one it is, and he cannot find other water, he said: "Spill them both and perform tayammum (dry ablution)."
49 - 4 Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Yahya from al-'Umraki from Ali bin Ja'far from his brother Musa bin Ja'far, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a chicken, a dove, and similar things that step on excrement and then enter the water. Is it permissible to perform ablution with it for prayer? He said: "No, unless the water is abundant, the size of a Kurr (volume of water)."
50 - 5 As for what al-Hussein bin Saeed narrated from al-Qasim bin Muhammad from Ali bin Abi Hamza, who said:
I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, (about stagnant water (1) in which there is a carcass, is it permissible to use it for istinja' (cleaning oneself after relieving oneself)? (2) He said:) "Perform ablution from the other side, and do not perform ablution from the side of the carcass."
51 - 6 From him, from Uthman bin Isa, from Sama'a who said: I asked him about a man who passes by a dead animal in the water, he said (3): "Perform ablution from the side where the dead animal is not."
52 - 7 And from him, from al-Qasim bin Muhammad, from Aban, from Zakkar bin Farqad, from Uthman bin Ziyad who said:
I said to Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him: I am traveling and I come to al-Naqi' water (standing water) and my hand is dirty, so I dip it in the water. He said: "There is no harm."

text:
53 - 8 محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن محمد بن عبد الجبار عن محمد بن سنان عن العلا بن الفضيل قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الحياض يبال فيها فقال: لا باس إذا غلب لون الماء لون البول.
54 - 9 أحمد بن محمد عن أحمد بن محمد بن أبي نصر عن صفوان بن مهران الجمال قال:
سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الحياض التي ما بين مكة إلى المدينة تردها السباع وتلغ فيها الكلاب، وتشرب منها الحمير، ويغتسل منها (1) الجنب أيتوضأ (2) منها (3) فقال: وكم قدر الماء قلت: إلى نصف الساق والى الركبة فقال: توضأ منه (4).
55 - 10 الحسين بن سعيد عن فضالة بن أيوب عن الحسين بن عثمان عن سماعة بن مهران عن أبي بصير قال: قلت لأبي عبد الله عليه السلام إنا نسافر فربما بلينا بالغدير من المطر يكون إلى جانب القرية فتكون فيه العذرة ويبول فيه الصبي وتبول فيه الدابة وتروث فقال: ان عرض في قلبك منه شئ فافعل (5) هكذا يعني افرج الماء بيدك ثم توضأ فان الدين ليس بمضيق فان الله عز وجل يقول (ما جعل عليكم في الدين من حرج).
فالوجه في هذه الأخبار كلها ان نحملها على أنه إذا كان الماء أكثر من كر فإنه إذا كان كذلك لا ينجس بما يقع فيه إلا أن يتغير أحد أوصافه حسب ما قدمناه وما تضمنت (6) من الامر بالوضوء من الجانب الذي ليس فيه الجيفة، أو بتفريج الماء يكون محمولا على الاستحباب والتنزه لان النفس تعاف مماسة الماء الذي تجاوره

الجيفة، وإن كان حكمه حكم الطاهر (1) والذي يدل على ذلك ما قدمناه من الاخبار من أن حد الماء الذي لا ينجسه شئ ما يكون مقداره مقدار كر (2) وإذا نقص عنه نجس بما يحصل فيه ويزيد على ذلك بيانا:
56 - 11 ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن عثمان بن عيسى عن سعيد الأعرج قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الجرة تسع مائة رطل يقع فيها أوقية من دم اشرب منه وأتوضأ قال: لا.
57 - 12 فاما ما رواه محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن محمد بن أحمد العلوي عن العمركي عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى عليه السلام قال: سألته عن رجل رعف فامتخط فصار ذلك الدم قطعا صغارا فأصاب إناءه هل يصلح الوضوء منه قال: إن لم يكن شئ يستبين في الماء فلا باس وإن كان شيئا بينا فلا يتوضأ منه.
فالوجه في هذا الخبر أن نحمله على أنه إذا كان ذلك الدم مثل رأس (3) الإبرة التي لا تحس ولا ندرك فان مثل ذلك معفو عنه.
11 - باب حكم الفارة والوزغة والحية والعقرب إذا وقع في الماء وخرج منه حيا 58 - 1 اخبرني الحسين بن عبيد الله عن أحمد بن محمد بن يحيى عن أبيه عن محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن العمركي عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى عليه السلام قال: سألته عن العظاية (4) والحية والوزغ يقع في الماء فلا يموت أيتوضأ منه للصلاة فقال: لا باس به.

The carrion, even though its ruling is that of the pure (1), is supported by the narrations we presented earlier, stating that the limit of water that nothing can make impure is the amount of a *Kurr* (2). If it is less than that, it becomes impure by what falls into it. To further clarify this:

56 - 11: What Al-Hussein bin Saeed narrated from Othman bin Issa from Saeed Al-Araj, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a jar that holds nine hundred *Ratl* (pounds) into which an *Oqiya* (ounce) of blood falls, can I drink from it and perform ablution with it? He said: No.

57 - 12: As for what Muhammad bin Ali bin Mahbub narrated from Muhammad bin Ahmed Al-Alawi from Al-'Umraki from Ali bin Jaafar from his brother Musa, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a man who had a nosebleed and blew his nose, and that blood became small pieces that fell into his vessel, is it permissible to perform ablution with it? He said: If there is nothing apparent in the water, then there is no harm, but if something is apparent, then one should not perform ablution with it.

The interpretation of this narration is that we understand it to mean that if that blood is like the head (3) of a needle that is not felt or perceived, then such a thing is excused.

11 - Chapter on the ruling of a mouse, gecko, snake, and scorpion if they fall into water and come out alive.

58 - 1: Al-Hussein bin Ubaid Allah informed me from Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Yahya from his father from Muhammad bin Ahmed bin Yahya from Al-'Umraki from Ali bin Jaafar from his brother Musa, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about the *Iẓāyah* (4), snake, and gecko falling into the water and not dying, is it permissible to perform ablution with it for prayer? He said: There is no harm in it.

59 - 2 محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن محمد بن الحسين بن أبي الخطاب والحسن بن موسى الخشاب جميعا عن يزيد بن إسحاق عن هارون بن حمزة الغنوي عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: سألته عن الفارة والعقرب وأشباه ذلك يقع في الماء فيخرج حيا هل يشرب من ذلك الماء ويتوضأ منه قال: يسكب منه ثلث مرات وقليله وكثيرة بمنزلة واحدة ثم يشرب منه (1) (ويتوضأ منه) (2) غير الوزغ فإنه لا ينتفع بما يقع فيه.
قال: الشيخ أبو جعفر محمد بن الحسن رحمه الله ما تضمن هذا الخبر من حكم الوزغة والامر بإراقة ما يقع فيه محمول على ضرب من الكراهية بدلالة الخبر المتقدم ولا يجوز التنافي بين الاخبار.
60 - 3 فاما ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن محمد بن عيسى اليقطيني عن النضر بن سويد عن عمر بن شمر عن جابر عن أبي جعفر (3) عليه السلام قال:
أتاه رجل فقال: له وقعت فارة في خابية (4) فيها سمن أو زيت فما ترى في اكله فقال: له أبو جعفر عليه السلام لا تأكله فقال: له الرجل الفارة أهون علي من أن اترك طعامي من اجلها قال: فقال له (5) أبو جعفر عليه السلام انك لم تستخف بالفارة إنما استخففت بدينك ان الله حرم الميتة من كل شئ فلا (6) ينافي الخبر الأول لان الوجه في هذا الخبر انه إذا ماتت الفارة فيه لا يجوز الانتفاع به، فاما إذا خرجت حية كان الحكم ما تضمنه الخبر الأول يدل على ذلك.
61 - 4 ما رواه علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى بن جعفر عليه السلام قال: سألته عن فارة وقعت في حب دهن فأخرجت قبل ان تموت أنبيعه من مسلم قال: نعم وتدهن منه.

59 - 2 Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Yahya, from Muhammad bin al-Hussein bin Abi al-Khattab and al-Hasan bin Musa al-Khashab, all from Yazid bin Ishaq, from Harun bin Hamza al-Ghanawi, from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a mouse, a scorpion, and similar things that fall into water and come out alive, is it permissible to drink from that water and perform ablution with it? He said: "Pour out a third of it three times; little or much, it is the same. Then drink from it and perform ablution with it," (1) (and perform ablution with it) (2) except for the gecko, for one cannot benefit from what it falls into.

The Sheikh Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin al-Hasan, may God have mercy on him, said: "What this report includes regarding the ruling on the gecko and the order to pour out what it falls into is to be interpreted as a form of disapproval, as indicated by the preceding report. It is not permissible to have contradictions between the reports."

60 - 3 As for what Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Yahya narrated from Muhammad bin Isa al-Yaqtini, from al-Nadr bin Suwaid, from Omar bin Shimr, from Jabir, from Abi Ja'far, (3) peace be upon him, who said:
A man came to him and said: "A mouse fell into a *khabiyah* (4) containing ghee or oil. What do you think about eating from it?" Abi Ja'far, peace be upon him, said to him: "Do not eat it." The man said to him: "A mouse is easier for me than to leave my food because of it." He (5) Abi Ja'far, peace be upon him, said to him: "You have not taken the mouse lightly; rather, you have taken your religion lightly. God has forbidden carrion of everything." So (6) it does not contradict the first report, because the explanation for this report is that if the mouse dies in it, it is not permissible to benefit from it. But if it comes out alive, then the ruling is what the first report includes, which indicates that."

61 - 4 What Ali bin Ja'far narrated from his brother Musa bin Ja'far, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a mouse that fell into a jug of oil and was taken out before it died. "Should I sell it to a Muslim?" He said: "Yes, and anoint yourself with it."

64 - 1 Al-Hussein ibn Ubaid Allah informed me from several of our companions from Muhammad ibn Ya'qub from Ahmad ibn Idris from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya from Ahmad ibn al-Hasan ibn Ali from Amr ibn Saeed from Musaddiq ibn Sadaqa from Ammar al-Sabbati from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "He was asked about water that pigeons drink from." This is a general statement permitting the use of the leftovers of all animals whose meat is lawful to eat, and that the leftovers of what is unlawful to eat are not permissible to use. We have also clarified in our book "Tahdhib al-Ahkam" what is related to this, and we have fully covered the narrations in it. What this narration implies regarding the permissibility of using the leftovers of birds whose meat is not lawful to eat, such as the falcon and the saker falcon, if their beaks are free of blood, is an exception among what is not lawful to eat in terms of the permissibility of using its leftovers.
65 - 2 Likewise, what Ishaq bin Ammar narrated from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him): Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him) used to say: There is nothing wrong with the leftovers of a mouse if it drinks from a vessel; it is permissible to drink from it and perform ablution with it.
The justification for this is to exclude it (1) from among what is not lawful to eat, because it is impossible to avoid mice and it is difficult for a person to do so. Therefore, its leftovers are excused for that reason.
13 - Chapter on what does not have flowing blood that falls into water and dies in it 66 - 1 Al-Hussein bin Ubaidullah narrated to me from Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Yahya from his father from Muhammad bin Ahmed bin Yahya from Ahmed bin Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Faddal from Amr bin Saeed from Musaddiq bin Sadaqah from Ammar al-Sabbati from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: He was asked about the beetle, the fly, the locust, the ant, and the like, that die in the well, oil, ghee, and the like. The meaning of this narration is that nothing corrupts it in a way that makes it impermissible to benefit from any of it except after draining all of it, except what it changes. As for what has not changed, then a certain amount is drained from it and the rest is benefited from as we have explained in the book "Tahdhib al-Ahkam."

88 - 9 As for what Ahmad ibn Muhammad narrated from Ibn Mahbub from al-Hasan ibn Salih al-Thawri from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "If the water in the reservoirs is a kurr, nothing makes it impure." I said: "And how much is a kurr?" He said: "Three and a half spans in length, three and a half spans in depth, and three and a half spans in width." This narration can have two interpretations: one is that what is meant by "reservoirs" is the artificial pool that does not have a spring source, unlike the wells that have a source, because that is what is taken into account with the measure of the kurr, as we have explained. The second is that this may have been stated as a form of taqiyya (dissimulation), because some of the jurists equate between wells and puddles in their smallness and abundance. It is possible that the narration came in agreement with them. What clarifies this is that al-Hasan ibn Salih, the narrator of this hadith, is a Zaydi Batri, whose hadith is rejected in what he alone narrates.

101 - 5 وروى سعد بن عبد الله عن أيوب بن نوح النخعي عن محمد بن أبي حمزة عن علي بن يقطين عن أبي الحسن موسى بن جعفر عليه السلام قال: سألته عن البئر يقع فيها الحمامة والدجاجة أو الفارة أو الكلب أو الهرة فقال: يجزيك أن تنزح منها دلاء فان ذلك يطهرها انشاء الله تعالى.
فالوجه في هذه الأخبار أحد شيئين إما أن يكون عليه السلام أجاب عن حكم بعض ما تضمنه السؤال من الفارة والطير وعول في حكم الباقي على المعروف من مذهبه أو غيره من الاخبار التي شاعت عنهم عليهم السلام، والثاني أن لا يكون في ذلك تناف لان قوله تنزح (2) منها دلاء فإنه جمع الكثرة وهو ما زاد على العشرة ولا يمتنع أن يكون المراد به أربعين دلوا حسب ما تضمنته الاخبار الأولة، ولو كان المراد بها دون العشرة لكان جمعه يأتي على أفعله دون فعال على أنه قد حصل العلم بحصول النجاسة وبنزح أربعين دلوا يزول حكم النجاسة أيضا وذلك معلوم وما دون ذلك طريقة أخبار الآحاد فينبغي أن يكون العمل على ما قلنا.
102 - 6 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن ابن أبي عمير عن جميل بن دراج عن أبي أسامة زيد الشحام عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في الفارة والسنور والدجاجة والكلب والطير قال: فإذا لم يتفسخ أو لم يتغير طعم الماء فيكفيك خمس دلاء وإن تغير الماء فخذ منه حتى يذهب الريح.
فهذا الخبر أيضا يحتمل وجهين، أحدهما هو الذي ذكرناه في الاخبار الأولة وهو

100 - 4 And from him, from al-Qasim, from Aban, from Abi al-'Abbas al-Fadl al-Baqbaq, who said: Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said regarding a well into which a mouse, an animal, a dog, or a bird falls and dies: "It is taken out, then several buckets are drawn from the well, and then one can drink from it and perform ablution."
101 - 5 And Sa'd ibn Abdullah narrated from Ayyub ibn Nuh al-Nakh'i, from Muhammad ibn Abi Hamza, from Ali ibn Yaqtin, from Abi al-Hasan Musa ibn Jaafar, peace be upon him, who said: "I asked him about a well into which a dove, a chicken, a mouse, a dog, or a cat falls, and he said: 'It suffices you to draw several buckets from it, for that purifies it, God willing.'"
The explanation of these narrations is one of two things: either that, peace be upon him, answered regarding the ruling of some of what the question included concerning the mouse and the bird, and relied in the ruling of the rest on what is known from his school of thought or other narrations that have become widespread from them, peace be upon them. The second is that there is no contradiction in that, because his saying "draw (2) several buckets from it," for it is a plural of abundance, which is what exceeds ten. And it is not impossible that what is meant by it is forty buckets, according to what the earlier narrations included. And if what was meant by it was less than ten, then its plural would come in the form of "af'ulah" rather than "fi'al." However, knowledge has been obtained of the occurrence of impurity, and by drawing forty buckets, the ruling of impurity also disappears, and that is known. And what is less than that is the method of the narrations of individuals, so the action should be based on what we said.
102 - 6 As for what al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Jamil ibn Darraj, from Abi Usama Zaid al-Shahham, from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, regarding the mouse, the cat, the chicken, the dog, and the bird, he said: "If it does not decompose or the taste of the water does not change, then five buckets suffice you, and if the water changes, then take from it until the odor goes away."

21 - باب البئر يقع فيها الفارة والوزغة والسام أبرص 106 - 1 اخبرني الشيخ أبو عبد الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن الحسين بن الحسن ابن أبان عن الحسين بن سعيد عن حماد وفضالة عن معاوية بن عمار قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الفارة والوزغة تقع في البئر قال: ينزح منها ثلث دلاء.
107 - 2 وعنه عن فضالة عن ابن سنان عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام مثله.
108 - 3 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن القاسم عن علي قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الفارة تقع في البئر قال: سبع دلاء.
109 - 4 وعنه عن عثمان بن عيسى عن سماعة قال: سألته عن الفارة تقع في البئر أو الطير قال: ان أدركته قبل أن ينتن نزحت منها سبع دلاء.
فالوجه في هذين الخبرين أن نحملهما على أن الفارة إذا كانت قد تفسخت فإنه ينزح منها سبع دلاء والخبران الأولان نحملهما على أنها أخرجت قبل أن تتفسخ، والذي يدل على هذا التفصيل.
110 - 5 ما اخبرني به الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن علي بن الحكم عن عثمان بن عبد الملك عن أبي سعيد المكاري عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: إذا وقعت الفارة في البئر فتسلخت (1) فانزح منها سبع دلاء فجاء هذا الخبر مفسرا للاخبار كلها.

21 - Chapter on a well into which a mouse, gecko, or house lizard falls

106 - 1 - Abu Abdullah narrated to me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from his father from al-Hussein ibn al-Hasan ibn Aban from al-Hussein ibn Saeed from Hammad and Fadalah from Muawiyah ibn Ammar who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a mouse or gecko that falls into a well. He said: "Draw out a third of a دلو (bucket)."

107 - 2 And from him, from Fadalah, from Ibn Sinan, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) similarly.

108 - 3 - As for what al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from al-Qasim from Ali, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a mouse that falls into a well. He said: "Seven دلو (buckets)."

109 - 4 - And from him, from Uthman ibn Isa, from Sama'a, who said: I asked him about a mouse or bird that falls into a well. He said: "If you find it before it decomposes, draw out seven دلو (buckets)."

The interpretation of these two narrations is that we understand them to mean that if the mouse has decomposed, then seven دلو (buckets) should be drawn out. The first two narrations, we interpret as meaning that it was taken out before it decomposed. What indicates this distinction is:

110 - 5 - What Abu Abdullah (may Allah have mercy on him) narrated to me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from his father from Saad ibn Abdullah from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from Ali ibn al-Hakam from Uthman ibn Abd al-Malik from Abu Saeed al-Makkari from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "If a mouse falls into a well and decomposes (1), then draw out seven دلو (buckets) from it." This narration came as an explanation for all the narrations.

111 - 6 فأما ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن محمد بن الحسن (1) عن عبد الرحمن ابن أبي هاشم عن أبي خديجة عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: سئل عن الفارة تقع في البئر قال: إذا ماتت ولم تنتن فأربعين دلوا وإذا انتفخت فيه وأنتنت نزح الماء كله فالوجه فيما تضمن هذا الخبر من الامر بنزح أربعين دلوا إذا لم تنتن فمحمول (2) على ضرب من الاستحباب دون الفرض والايجاب لان الوجوب في هذا المقدار لم يعتبره أحد من أصحابنا.
112 - 7 فأما ما رواه أحمد بن محمد بن عيسى عن علي بن حديد عن بعض أصحابنا قال: كنت مع أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في طريق مكة فصرنا إلى بئر فأستقي غلام أبي عبد الله عليه السلام دلوا فخرج فيه فارتان فقال: أبو عبد الله عليه السلام ارقه فاستقى آخر فخرج فيه فارة فقال: أبو عبد الله عليه السلام ارقه فاستقى الثالث فلم يخرج فيه شئ فقال: صبه في الاناء فصبه في الاناء فأول ما في هذا الخبر انه مرسل وراويه ضعيف وهو علي بن حديد وهذا يضعف الاحتجاج بخبره، ويحتمل مع تسليمه أن يكون المراد بالبئر المصنع الذي فيه من الماء ما يزيد مقداره على الكر فلا يجب نزح شئ منه وذلك هو المعتاد في طريق مكة مع أنه ليس في الخبر انه توضأ بذلك الماء بل قال: لغلامه صبه في الاناء وليس في ذلك دليل على جواز استعمال ما هذا حكمه في الوضوء، ويجوز أن يكون إنما أمره بالصب في الاناء لاحتياجهم إليه لسقي الدواب والإبل أو للشرب عند الضرورة الداعية إليه وذلك سايغ ويحتمل أيضا أن تكون الفارتان خرجتا حيتين وإذا كان كذلك جاز استعمال ما بقي من الماء على ما تقدم فيما مضى ويزيده بيانا.

111 - 6 As for what Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated from Muhammad ibn al-Hasan (1) from Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Hashem from Abi Khadija from Abi Abd Allah, peace be upon him, who said: He was asked about a mouse falling into a well, and he said: If it dies and does not become putrid, then forty buckets [should be drawn], and if it swells up in it and becomes putrid, then all the water should be drained. The interpretation of what this report includes regarding the command to draw forty buckets when it does not become putrid is that it is to be understood (2) as a form of recommendation, not an obligation and a necessity, because the obligation of this amount has not been considered by any of our companions.
112 - 7 As for what Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Isa narrated from Ali ibn Hadid from some of our companions who said: I was with Abi Abd Allah, peace be upon him, on the road to Mecca, and we came to a well. The servant of Abi Abd Allah, peace be upon him, drew a bucket, and two mice came out in it. Abi Abd Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Throw it away." He drew another, and a mouse came out in it. Abi Abd Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Throw it away." He drew a third, and nothing came out in it. He said: "Pour it into the vessel." So he poured it into the vessel. The first thing about this report is that it is mursal (interrupted), and its narrator is weak, and he is Ali ibn Hadid, and this weakens the argument based on his report. It is possible, while accepting it, that what is meant by the well is the artificial reservoir in which the amount of water exceeds the volume of a "kurr," so it is not obligatory to drain anything from it, and that is what is common on the road to Mecca. Moreover, it is not mentioned in the report that he performed ablution with that water, but he said to his servant: "Pour it into the vessel," and there is no evidence in that to permit using water of this kind for ablution. It is permissible that he only ordered him to pour it into the vessel because they needed it to water the animals and camels or to drink in case of necessity, and that is permissible. It is also possible that the two mice that came out were alive, and if that was the case, it would be permissible to use the remaining water based on what has preceded in the past, and this will make it clearer.

113 - 8 The Sheikh Abu Abdullah, may God have mercy on him, narrated to me from Abu Ja'far Muhammad ibn Ali ibn al-Hussein ibn Babawayh, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Yahya, from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya, from Muhammad ibn al-Hussein ibn Abi al-Khattab and al-Hasan ibn Musa al-Khashab, all from Yazid ibn Ishaq, from Harun ibn Hamza al-Ghanawi, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: I asked him about a mouse, a scorpion, and the like falling into water and coming out alive. Then, one can drink from it and perform ablution with it, except for the gecko, as nothing that falls into it is beneficial."

I said to Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him: "We found a gecko disintegrated in the well." He said: "You only need to draw out seven buckets from it."

This does not contradict the first narration because the first narration is to be understood as recommended, and this narration conforms to what we have presented of narrations that what does not have flowing blood does not render the water impure by its death, and the gecko is of that kind.

يحيى (1) عن ابن مسكان قال: حدثني أبو بصير قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن العذرة تقع في البئر فقال: ينزح منها عشر دلاء فان ذابت فأربعون أو خمسون دلوا.
117 - 2 فأما ما رواه سعد بن عبد الله عن أحمد بن الحسن عن عمرو بن سعيد عن مصدق بن صدقة عن عمار قال: سئل أبو عبد الله عليه السلام عن البئر يقع فيها زنبيل عذرة يابسة أو رطبة فقال: لا بأس إذا كان فيها ماء كثير.
118 - 3 وما رواه محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن محمد بن الحسين عن موسى بن القاسم عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى بن جعفر عليه السلام قال: سألته عن بئر ماء وقع فيها زنبيل من عذرة يابسة أو رطبة أو زنبيل من سرقين أيصلح الوضوء منها؟
فقال: لا بأس.
فالوجه في هذين الخبرين أحد شيئين، أحدهما أن يكون المراد به انه لا بأس به بعد نزح خمسين دلوا حسب ما تضمنه الخبر الأول، والثاني أن يكون المراد بالبئر المصنع الذي يكون فيه من الماء أكثر من كر ولأجل هذا قال: لا باس به إذا كان فيها ماء كثير لان ذلك هو الذي يعتبر فيه القلة والكثرة دون الآبار المعينة.
119 - 4 فأما ما رواه سعد بن عبد الله عن موسى بن الحسن عن أبي القاسم عبد الرحمن بن حماد (2) الكوفي عن بشير عن أبي مريم الأنصاري قال: كنت مع أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في حائط له فحضرت الصلاة فنزح دلوا للوضوء من ركي له فخرج عليه قطعة من عذرة يابسة فأكفى رأسه وتوضأ بالباقي.

132 - 1 فاما ما رواه محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن الهيثم بن أبي مسروق عن محمد بن إسماعيل قال: دخلت على أبي الحسن الرضا عليه السلام وفي منزله كنيف مستقبل القبلة.
فلا ينافي هذا الخبر الخبرين الأولين لأنه ليس فيه أكثر من أنه شاهد كنيفا قد بني على هذا الوجه ولم يذكر انه شاهده عليه قاعدا أو سوغ ذلك أو أمر ببنائه على هذا الوجه، ويجوز أن يكون قد انتقل الدار إليه وقد بني كذلك فإنه إذا كان الامر على ذلك لجاز الجلوس عليه.

Muhammad ibn al-Hasan (1) said: This report indicates that all the preceding reports are to be understood as recommending a practice, not prohibiting or obligating it.

26 - Chapter on Facing and Turning Away from the Qibla when Urinating and Defecating
130 - 1 The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, informed me, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Yahya, from Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Mahbub, from Muhammad ibn al-Hussein, from Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Zurara, from Isa ibn Abdullah al-Hashimi, from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali, peace be upon him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family, said: "When you enter the place of excretion, do not face the Qibla nor turn your back to it, but face east or west."
131 - 2 With the same chain of transmission, from Muhammad ibn Yahya, from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya, from Yaqub ibn Yazid, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Abd al-Hamid ibn Abi al-Ala or someone else who elevated it (to the Prophet): Al-Hasan ibn Ali, peace be upon them, was asked: "What are the limits of defecation?" He said: "Do not face the Qibla, nor turn your back to it, nor face the wind, nor turn your back to it."
132 - 1 As for what Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Mahbub narrated from al-Haytham ibn Abi Masruq, from Muhammad ibn Ismail, who said: "I entered upon Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha, peace be upon him, and in his house was a privy facing the Qibla."

This report does not contradict the first two reports because it contains no more than that he saw a privy that had been built in this manner. It does not mention that he saw him sitting on it, or that he permitted that, or that he commanded it to be built in this manner. It is possible that the house was transferred to him after it had been built in this way, and if the matter was like that, it would be permissible to sit upon it.

27 - باب من أراد الاستنجاء وفي يده اليسرى خاتم عليه اسم من أسماء الله تعالى 113 - 1 اخبرني الشيخ (1) رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن أحمد بن إدريس عن محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن أحمد بن الحسن بن علي بن فضال عن عمرو بن سعيد عن مصدق بن صدقه عن عمار الساباطي عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام أنه قال:
لا يمس الجنب درهما ولا دينارا عليه اسم الله ولا يستنجي وعليه خاتم فيه اسم الله ولا يجامع وهو عليه ولا يدخل المخرج وهو عليه.
134 - 2 فأما ما رواه أحمد بن محمد عن البرقي عن وهب بن وهب عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: كان نقش خاتم أبي (العزة لله جميعا) وكان في يساره يستنجي بها، وكان نقش خاتم أمير المؤمنين عليه السلام (الملك لله) وكان في يده اليسرى ويستنجي بها.
فهذا الخبر محمول على التقية لان رواية وهب بن وهب وهو عامي ضعيف متروك الحديث فيها يختص به على أن ما قدمناه من آداب الطهارة وليس من واجباتها والذي يدل على ذلك.
135 - 3 ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن سهل بن زياد عن علي بن الحكم عن أبان بن عثمان عن أبي القاسم عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: قلت: له الرجل يريد الخلاء وعليه خاتم فيه اسم الله تعالى قال: ما أحب ذلك قال: فيكون اسم محمد صلى الله عليه وآله قال: لا بأس.

27 - Chapter on one who intends to cleanse (Istinja) while having a ring on his left hand with a name from the names of Allah the Exalted 113 - 1 The Sheikh (1) (may Allah have mercy on him) narrated to me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Ahmad ibn Idris, from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya, from Ahmad ibn al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Faddal, from Amr ibn Saeed, from Musaddiq ibn Sadaqa, from Ammar al-Sabbati, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said:
The one who is in a state of ritual impurity (Janaba) should not touch a dirham or dinar that has the name of Allah on it, nor should he cleanse (Istinja) while wearing a ring with the name of Allah on it, nor should he have sexual intercourse while wearing it, nor should he enter the lavatory while wearing it.
134 - 2 As for what Ahmad ibn Muhammad narrated from al-Barqi, from Wahb ibn Wahb, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: The inscription on my father's ring was "(All) might belongs to Allah," and it was on his left hand, and he would cleanse with it. And the inscription on the ring of Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) was "(The) kingdom belongs to Allah," and it was on his left hand, and he would cleanse with it.
This report is to be understood as taqiyya (dissimulation), because the narration of Wahb ibn Wahb, who is a commoner, is weak and his hadith is abandoned, in which he is unique. Furthermore, what we have presented is from the etiquettes of purification and not from its obligations, and what indicates that is:
135 - 3 What Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated from Sahl ibn Ziyad, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Aban ibn Uthman, from Abi al-Qasim, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: I said to him: A man wants to go to the toilet and he is wearing a ring with the name of Allah the Exalted on it. He said: I do not like that. He said: What if it is the name of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family)? He said: There is no harm.

يجزي من البول أن تغسله بمثله.

30 - باب غسل اليدين قبل ادخالهما الاناء عند واحد من الاحداث 141 - 1 اخبرني الحسين بن عبيد الله عن أحمد بن محمد بن يحيى عن أبيه عن محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن ابن أبي عمير عن حماد عن الحلبي قال:
سألته عن الوضوء كم يفرغ الرجل على يده اليمنى قبل أن يدخلها في الاناء؟ قال:
واحدة من حدث البول واثنتان من الغائط (1) وثلاث من الجنابة.
142 - 2 وبهذا الاسناد عن محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن علي بن السندي عن حماد بن عيسى عن حريز عن أبي جعفر عليه السلام قال: يغسل الرجل يده من النوم مرة ومن الغائط والبول مرتين ومن الجنابة ثلاثا.
143 - 3 فأما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن صفوان بن يحيى وفضالة بن أيوب عن العلا ابن رزين عن محمد بن مسلم عن أحدهما عليهما السلام قال: سألته عن الرجل يبول ولا يمس يده اليمنى شئ (2) أيغمسها في الماء؟ قال: نعم وإن كان جنبا.

30 - Chapter on Washing the Hands Before Immersing Them in the Vessel After One of the Ritual Impurities 141 - 1 Al-Husayn ibn ʿUbayd Allāh informed me, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Yahyā, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahyā, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Ibn Abī ʿUmayr, from Hammād, from al-Halabī, who said:

Once for ritual impurity from urine, twice for defecation (1), and three times for sexual impurity.
142 - 2 And with this chain of narrators, from Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahyā, from ʿAlī ibn al-Sindī, from Hammād ibn ʿĪsā, from Hurayz, from Abī Jaʿfar (peace be upon him), who said: A man should wash his hand once after sleeping, twice after defecation and urination, and three times after sexual impurity.
143 - 3 As for what al-Husayn ibn Saʿīd narrated from Safwān ibn Yahyā and Fadāla ibn Ayyūb, from al-ʿAlā’ ibn Razīn, from Muhammad ibn Muslim, from one of them (peace be upon them both), who said: I asked him about a man who urinates and nothing touches his right hand (2): Should he immerse it in the water? 156 - 11 سعد عن أحمد بن محمد عن العباس بن معروف عن علي بن مهزيار عن محمد بن يحيى الخزاز عن عمرو بن أبي نصر قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الرجل يبول فينسى (1) أن يغسل ذكره ويتوضأ؟ قال: يغسل ذكره ولا يعيد وضوئه.
157 - 12 فأما ما رواه سعد (2) عن موسى بن الحسن، والحسن بن علي عن أحمد بن هلال عن محمد بن أبي عمير عن هشام بن سالم عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في الرجل يتوضأ وينسى أن يغسل ذكره وقد بال؟ فقال: يغسل ذكره ولا يعيد الصلاة.
فهذا الخبر يمكن أن نحمله على من نسي غسل ذكره بالماء ثم ذكر وقد عدم الماء جاز أن يستبيح الصلاة بما تقدم من الاستنجاء بالأحجار ولا يلزمه إعادة صلاة يصليها بعد ذلك والحال على ما وصفناه فإذا وجد الماء وجب عليه إعادة غسل الموضع ولا يلزمه إعادة الصلاة التي صلاها عند عدم الماء.

فمحمول على الاستحباب والندب بدلالة الأخبار المتقدمة التي تضمنت انه لا يجب عليه إعادة الوضوء ولا يجوز التناقض في أقوالهم.

ابن بشير البجلي عن حماد بن عثمان عن عمار بن موسى قال: سمعت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام يقول: لو أن رجلا نسي أن يستنجي من الغايط حتى يصلي لم يعد الصلاة.
فالوجه في هذا الخبر أنه نسي أن يستنجي بالماء وإن كان قد استنجى بالأحجار فإنه إذا كان كذلك لا يلزمه إعادة الصلاة، يدل على ذلك ما تقدم من الاخبار ويزيد ذلك بيانا.
160 - 15 ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن حماد عن حريز عن زرارة عن أبي جعفر عليه السلام قال: لا صلاة الا بطهور ويجزيك من الاستنجاء ثلاثة أحجار بذلك جرت السنة من رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله وأما البول فإنه لابد من غسله.
161 - 16 فأما ما رواه محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن أحمد بن محمد عن موسى بن القاسم عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى بن جعفر عليه السلام قال: سألته عن رجل ذكر وهو في صلاته انه لم يستنج من الخلاء قال: ينصرف ويستنجي من الخلاء ويعيد الصلاة وإن ذكر وقد فرغ من صلاته فقد أجزأه ذلك ولا إعادة عليه.
فالوجه فيه أيضا ما ذكرناه من أنه إذا ذكر انه لم يستنج بالماء وإن كان قد استنجى بالحجر فحينئذ يستحب له الانصراف من الصلاة ما دام فيها ويستنجي بالماء ويعيد الصلاة وإذا انصرف منها لم يكن عليه شئ ولو كان لم يستنج أصلا لكان عليه إعادة الصلاة على كل حال انصرف أو لم ينصرف على ما بيناه ويزيد ذلك بيانا:
162 - 17 ما رواه محمد بن يعقوب عن علي بن إبراهيم عن محمد بن عيسى عن يونس عن زرعة عن سماعة قال: قال: أبو عبد الله عليه السلام إذا دخلت الغايط فقضيت الحاجة فلم تهرق الماء ثم توضأت ونسيت أن تستنجي فذكرت بعد ما صليت فعليك الإعادة فان كنت أهرقت الماء فنسيت ان تغسل ذكرك حتى صليت فعليك إعادة الوضوء والصلاة وغسل ذكرك لان البول مثل البراز (1)

Ibn Bashir al-Bajali from Hammad ibn Uthman from Ammar ibn Musa, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say: If a man forgets to cleanse himself (istinja) after defecating and prays, he does not have to repeat the prayer.
The interpretation of this narration is that he forgot to cleanse himself with water. However, if he cleansed himself with stones, then he is not required to repeat the prayer. This is supported by the previous narrations and further clarifies the matter.
160 - 15 What al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from Hammad from Hurayz from Zurara from Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him), who said: There is no prayer without purification (tahur). Three stones are sufficient for cleansing (istinja), as this is the Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family). As for urine, it must be washed away.
161 - 16 As for what Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Mahbub narrated from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from Musa ibn al-Qasim from Ali ibn Jaafar from his brother Musa ibn Jaafar (peace be upon them), who said: I asked him about a man who remembered while in prayer that he had not cleansed himself after relieving himself. He said: He should leave, cleanse himself after relieving himself, and repeat the prayer. If he remembers after finishing the prayer, it is sufficient, and he does not have to repeat it.
The interpretation of this is also as we mentioned: if he remembers that he did not cleanse himself with water, even though he cleansed himself with stones, then it is recommended for him to leave the prayer as long as he is in it, cleanse himself with water, and repeat the prayer. If he finishes it, then there is nothing upon him. However, if he had not cleansed himself at all, he would have to repeat the prayer in any case, whether he leaves or does not leave, as we explained. This is further clarified by:
162 - 17 What Muhammad ibn Yaqub narrated from Ali ibn Ibrahim from Muhammad ibn Isa from Yunus from Zur'a from Sama'a, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: If you enter the toilet, relieve yourself, do not pour water, then perform ablution (wudu), and forget to cleanse (istinja), then remember after you have prayed, you must repeat it. If you poured water but forgot to wash your private parts until you prayed, you must repeat the ablution, the prayer, and wash your private parts, because urine is like feces. (1)

text:
عليه السلام أيجوز (1) للرجل أن يمسح قدميه بفضل رأسه؟ فقال: برأسه لا فقلت:
أبماء جديد؟ فقال: برأسه نعم.
174 - 4 وما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن حماد عن شعيب عن أبي بصير قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن مسح الرأس قلت: أمسح بما في يدي من الندى رأسي، فقال: لا بل تضع يدك في الماء ثم تمسح.
فالوجه في هذين الخبرين أن نحملهما على ضرب من التقية لأنهما موافقان لمذاهب كثير من العامة، ويحتمل أن يكون المراد بهما إذا جفت أعضاء الطهارة بتفريط من جهته فيحتاج أن يجدد غسلها فيأخذ ماء جديدا ويكون الاخذ لها اخذا للمسح حسب ما تضمنه الخبر الأول.
وأما الخبر الثاني فيحتمل أن يكون المراد بقوله بل تضع يدك في الماء إنما أراد به الماء الذي بقي في لحيته أو حاجبيه وليس فيه أن يضع يده في الماء الذي في الاناء أو غيره فإذا احتمل ذلك لم يعارض ما قدمناه من الاخبار، والذي يدل على التأويل الذي ذكرناه.
175 - 5 ما اخبرني به الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن موسى بن جعفر بن وهب عن الحسن بن علي الوشا عن خلف بن حماد عمن اخبره عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: قلت: له الرجل ينسى مسح رأسه وهو في الصلاة قال: إن كان في لحيته بلل فليمسح به قلت: فإن لم يكن له لحية قال: يمسح من حاجبيه أو من أشفار عينيه.

Peace be upon him. Is it permissible (1) for a man to wipe his feet with the excess moisture from his head? He said: Not with his head. So I said: With fresh water? He said: With his head, yes.
174 - 4 And what Al-Hussein bin Saeed narrated from Hammad, from Shuaib, from Abi Baseer, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about wiping the head. I said: Do I wipe my head with the moisture on my hand? He said: No, rather you place your hand in the water and then wipe.
The explanation for these two narrations is that we interpret them as a form of taqiyya (dissimulation), because they are in agreement with the doctrines of many of the common people. It is also possible that what is meant by them is if the limbs of purification dry out due to negligence on his part, then he needs to renew washing them, so he takes fresh water, and the taking of it is considered taking for the wiping, according to what the first narration implies.
As for the second narration, it is possible that what is meant by his saying, "Rather, you place your hand in the water," is that he only meant the water that remained in his beard or eyebrows, and it does not mean that he places his hand in the water that is in the vessel or elsewhere. If that is possible, then it does not contradict what we have presented from the narrations. What indicates the interpretation we mentioned.
175 - 5 What the Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, informed me of from Ahmed bin Muhammad, from his father, from Saad bin Abdullah, from Musa bin Jaafar bin Wahb, from Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Washa, from Khalaf bin Hammad, from someone who informed him from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: I said to him: A man forgets to wipe his head while he is in prayer. He said: If there is moisture in his beard, then let him wipe with it. I said: What if he does not have a beard? He said: He wipes from his eyebrows or from the edges of his eyes.

Then He connected "with it" to "your hands." Then He said: "with it," meaning with that dry ablution, because He knew that all of that would not adhere to the face, because some of that earth sticks to some of the hand and does not stick to other parts. I was performing ablution when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, approached as I began the ablution. He said to me: "Rinse your mouth, inhale water into your nostrils, and use the Siwak (1)." Then I washed three times, and he said, "Two times are sufficient for you." I washed my forearms and wiped my head twice, and he said, "One time is sufficient for you." I washed my feet, and he said to me, "O Ali, run your fingers between your toes, do not let the fire run through them."

This is a report that agrees with the common practice and was narrated in a context of taqiyya (dissimulation), because the well-known and undoubtedly established view from the doctrines of our Imams, peace be upon them, is the practice of wiping over the feet, and that is more famous than to be subject to doubt or uncertainty. This is clarified by the fact that all the narrators of this report are from the common people and men of the Zaidiyyah, and what they exclusively narrate is not acted upon, as has been clarified elsewhere.

38 - Chapter on rinsing the mouth and inhaling water into the nostrils. 197 - 1 The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, informed me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from his father from al-Hussein ibn al-Hassan ibn Aban from al-Hussein ibn Saeed from Uthman ibn Isa from Sama'ah, who said: "I asked him about them (rinsing the mouth and inhaling water)?" He said: "They are from the Sunnah. If you forget them, there is no need for you to repeat (the ablution)."

198 - 2 With this chain of narration, from Uthman ibn Isa from Ibn Muskan from Malik ibn A'yan, who said: "I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about someone who performed ablution and forgot rinsing the mouth and inhaling water, then remembered after he had entered into his prayer." He said: "There is no harm."

199 - 3 With this chain of narration, from al-Hussein ibn Saeed from Ibn Abi Umair from Jamil from Zurarah from Abu Jaafar, peace be upon him, who said: "Rinsing the mouth and inhaling water are not from the ablution."

Muhammad ibn al-Hassan al-Tusi (2), may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The meaning of his saying, peace be upon him, 'are not from the ablution' is that they are not from the obligatory acts of ablution, even though they are from its recommended acts. This is indicated by the first report that we narrated from Sama'ah, and is also confirmed by that."

The interpretation of this report is that we should understand the mentioning of the name in it to refer to the intention, which is proven to be obligatory. 213 - 5 As for what Al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from Hammad from Muawiyah ibn Wahb, he said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about ablution? He said: Twice, twice.

215 - 7 What Al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from Al-Qasim ibn Urwa from Ibn Bukayr from Zurara from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, he said: Ablution is twice, twice, and whoever increases it will not be rewarded for it. And he recounted to us the ablution of the Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him and his family, so he washed his face once, his arms once, and wiped his head with the remaining water, and his feet.
Muhammad ibn al-Hasan (1), may God have mercy on him, said: His recounting of the ablution of the Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him and his family, once, once, indicates that he meant by his saying: "Ablution is twice, twice" the Sunnah, because it is not permissible for the obligatory act to be twice while the Prophet, peace be upon him, does it once, once, with the consensus of Muslims that he shares with us in ablution and its manner. 42 - Chapter on the Obligation of Consecutive Performance in Ablution
220 - 1 The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated to me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Ahmad ibn Idris, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from al-Husayn ibn Sa'id, from Fadala ibn Ayyub, from al-Husayn ibn Uthman, from Sama'a, from Abu Basir, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "If you perform part of your ablution and a need arises for you until your ablution dries, then repeat your ablution, for ablution is not divisible."
221 - 2 And with this chain of narrators, from al-Husayn ibn Sa'id, from Mu'awiya ibn Ammar, who said: "I said to Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him: 'Sometimes I perform ablution and the water runs out, so I call the servant girl, and she delays in bringing me the water, so my ablution dries.' He said: 'Repeat it.'"
222 - 3 As for what Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Abdullah ibn al-Mughira, from Hurayz, concerning ablution that dries, he said: "I said: 'What if the first part dries before I wash the part that follows it?' He said: 'Whether it dries or does not dry, wash what remains.' I said: 'And is the same true for ritual bathing (ghusl) due to major impurity?' He said: 'It is of the same status. Begin with the head, then pour over the rest of your body.' I said: 'Even if it takes part of the day?' He said: 'Yes.'"
The interpretation of this report is that if the one performing ablution does not interrupt his ablution, but rather a strong wind or extreme heat dries it, then in that case, it is not obligatory for him to repeat it. Rather, repetition is obligatory in the separation of ablution with moderate weather and air. It is also possible that it was issued in the context of taqiyya (dissimulation), because that is the opinion of many of the common people (Sunnis).

224 - 1 وأخبرني ابن أبي جيد القمي عن محمد بن الحسن بن الوليد عن الحسين بن الحسن بن أبان عن الحسين بن سعيد عن محمد بن أبي عمير عن ابن أذينة عن زرارة قال: سئل أحدهما عن رجل بدأ بيده قبل وجهه وبرجليه قبل يديه، قال: يبدأ بما بدأ الله به وليعد ما كان " فعل " (3).
225 - 3 وبهذا الاسناد عن الحسين بن سعيد عن صفوان عن منصور بن حازم عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في الرجل يتوضأ فيبدأ بالشمال قبل اليمين قال: يغسل اليمين ويعيد اليسار.
226 - 4 فأما ما رواه سعد بن عبد الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن موسى بن القاسم وأبي

text:
قتادة عن علي بن جعفر عن أخيه موسى بن جعفر عليهما السلام قال: سألته عن رجل توضأ ونسي غسل يساره فقال: يغسل يساره وحدها ولا يعيد وضوء شئ غيرها.
فلا ينافي ما قدمناه من الترتيب لان معنى قوله: عليه السلام لا يعيد شيئا من وضوئه أنه لا يعيد شيئا مما تقدم من أعضائه قبل غسل يساره وإنما يجب عليه إتمام ما يلي هذا العضو والذي يدل على ذلك.
227 - 5 ما رواه محمد بن يعقوب عن عدة من أصحابنا عن أحمد بن محمد عن الحسين ابن سعيد عن فضالة بن أيوب عن الحسين بن عثمان عن سماعة عن أبي بصير عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: ان نسيت فغسلت ذراعيك قبل وجهك فأعد غسل وجهك ثم اغسل ذراعيك بعد الوجه، فان بدأت بذراعك الأيسر فأعد على الأيمن ثم اغسل اليسار، وإن نسيت مسح رأسك حتى تغسل رجليك فامسح رأسك ثم اغسل رجليك.
228 - 6 وعنه عن علي بن إبراهيم عن أبيه عن ابن أبي عمير عن حماد عن الحلبي عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: إذا نسي الرجل أن يغسل يمينه فغسل شماله ومسح رأسه ورجليه فذكر بعد ذلك غسل يمينه وشماله ومسح رأسه ورجليه، وإن كان إنما نسي شماله فليغسل الشمال ولا يعد على ما كان توضأ وقال: أتبع وضوءك بعضه بعضا.
229 - 7 الحسين عن القاسم بن عروة عن ابن بكير عن زرارة عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في الرجل نسي مسح رأسه حتى يدخل في الصلاة قال: إن كان في لحيته بلل بقدر ما يمسح رأسه ورجليه فليفعل ذلك وليصل قال: وإن نسي شيئا من الوضوء المفروض فعليه ان يبدأ بما نسي ويعيد ما بقي لتمام الوضوء.

Qatadah from Ali bin Ja'far from his brother Musa bin Ja'far, peace be upon them, who said: I asked him about a man who performed ablution and forgot to wash his left arm, he said: He should wash his left arm alone and not repeat any part of his ablution other than it.

This does not contradict what we have presented regarding sequence, because the meaning of his saying, peace be upon him, "He does not repeat anything of his ablution" is that he does not repeat anything from the parts that preceded the washing of his left arm, but rather he must complete what follows this part, and what indicates that is:

227-5 What Muhammad bin Ya'qub narrated from several of our companions, from Ahmad bin Muhammad, from al-Hussein bin Saeed, from Fadalah bin Ayyub, from al-Hussein bin Uthman, from Sama'a, from Abu Basir, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: If you forget and wash your arms before your face, then repeat washing your face, then wash your arms after the face. And if you start with your left arm, then repeat on the right, then wash the left. And if you forget to wipe your head until you wash your feet, then wipe your head, then wash your feet.

228-6 And from him, from Ali bin Ibrahim, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Hammad, from al-Halabi, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: If a man forgets to wash his right arm and washes his left arm and wipes his head and feet, and then remembers after that, he should wash his right and left arms and wipe his head and feet. But if he only forgot his left arm, then he should wash the left and not repeat what he had already performed of his ablution. And he said: Follow your ablution in sequence.

229-7 Al-Hussein from al-Qasim bin Urwa from Ibn Bukayr from Zurara from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, regarding a man who forgot to wipe his head until he entered the prayer, he said: If there is wetness in his beard sufficient to wipe his head and feet, then he should do that and pray. He said: And if he forgets anything from the obligatory ablution, then he must start with what he forgot and repeat what remains to complete the ablution.

رأسه بالحناء ثم يبدو له في الوضوء قال: لا يجوز حتى تصيب بشرة رأسه الماء.
فأول ما فيه أنه مرسل مقطوع الاسناد وما هذا حكمه لا يعارض به الاخبار المسندة ولو سلم لأمكن حمله على أنه إذا. أمكن إيصال الماء إلى البشرة فلابد من إيصاله وإذا لم يمكن ذلك، أو لحقه مشقة في إيصاله لم يجب عليه ويؤكد ذلك.
235 - 4 ما رواه سعد بن عبد الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن الحسن بن علي الوشا قال: سألت أبا الحسن عليه السلام عن الدواء إذا كان على يدي الرجل أيجزيه أن يمسح على طلاء الدواء فقال: نعم يجزيه أن يمسح عليه 45 - باب جواز التقية في المسح على الخفين 236 - 1 اخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن الحسين بن الحسن بن أبان عن الحسين بن سعيد عن فضالة عن حماد بن عثمان عن محمد بن النعمان عن أبي الورد قال: قلت لأبي جعفر عليه السلام إن أبا ظبيان حدثني انه رأى عليا عليه السلام أراق الماء ثم مسح على الخفين فقال: كذب أبو ظبيان أما بلغك قول علي عليه السلام فيكم، سبق الكتاب الخفين؟ فقلت: فهل فيهما رخصة؟ فقال:
لا إلا من عدو تتقيه أو ثلج تخاف على رجليك 237 - 2 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن حماد عن حريز عن زرارة قال: قلت له هل في مسح الخفين تقية؟ فقال: ثلاثة لا اتقي فيهن أحدا، شرب المسكر، ومسح الخفين ومتعة الحج فلا ينافي الخبر الأول لوجوه، أحدها انه أخبر عن نفسه انه لا يتقي فيه أحدا ويجوز أن يكون إنما أخبر بذلك لعلمه بأنه لا يحتاج إلى ما يتقي فيه في ذلك ولم يقل

...his head with henna, then it occurs to him to perform ablution, he said: It is not permissible until the water reaches the skin of his head."

The first thing about it is that it is *mursal* (a hadith with a missing link in the chain of narrators) and *maqtu' al-isnad* (a hadith with a broken chain of narrators). Such a ruling cannot be used to contradict *musnad* reports (a hadith with a complete chain of narrators). Even if we accept it, it can be interpreted to mean that if it is possible to deliver water to the skin, then it must be done. But if it is not possible, or if it causes hardship, then it is not obligatory. This is reinforced by what Sa'd bin Abdullah narrated from Ahmad bin Muhammad from al-Hasan bin Ali al-Washa, who said: I asked Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) about medicine, if it is on a man's hand, is it sufficient for him to wipe over the coating of the medicine? He said: Yes, it is sufficient for him to wipe over it.

45 - Chapter on the Permissibility of *Taqiyya* (Dissimulation) in Wiping Over the Leather Socks

236 - 1 The Sheikh (may Allah have mercy on him) informed me from Ahmad bin Muhammad from his father from al-Hussein bin al-Hasan bin Aban from al-Hussein bin Saeed from Fadala from Hammad bin Uthman from Muhammad bin al-Nu'man from Abi al-Ward who said: I said to Abi Ja'far (peace be upon him): Abu Zabyan narrated to me that he saw Ali (peace be upon him) urinating, then wiping over his leather socks. He said: Abu Zabyan lied. Has Ali's saying (peace be upon him) about you not reached you: "The Book (of Allah) preceded the leather socks?" I said: Is there a dispensation in them? He said: No, except from an enemy you fear or snow you fear for your feet.

فالوجه في هذا الخبر انه لا يجوز ذلك مع الاختيار فأما مع الضرورة فلا بأس به حسب ما تضمنه الخبر الأول 242 - 5 فأما ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن أحمد بن الحسن بن علي عن عمرو بن سعيد عن مصدق بن صدقة عن عمار بن موسى عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام في الرجل ينكسر ساعده أو موضع من مواضع الوضوء فلا يقدر ان يحله لحال الجبر إذا أجبر كيف يصنع؟ قال: إذا أراد أن يتوضأ فليضع اناء فيه ماء ويضع موضع الجبر في الماء حتى يصل الماء إلى جلده وقد أجزأه ذلك من غير أن يحله.

The explanation of this report is that we interpret it as a form of recommendation if that is possible and does not lead to harm. But if he fears harm from that, then nothing more than wiping over the bandages is required, as we have explained.

247 - 5 - وأخبرني الحسين بن عبيد الله عن أحمد بن محمد بن يحيى عن أبيه عن محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن عمران بن موسى عن الحسن بن علي بن النعمان عن أبيه عن (1) عبد الحميد بن عواض عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: سمعته يقول من نام وهو راكع أو ساجد أو ماش على أي الحالات فعليه الوضوء.

فأما ما رواه أبو عبيدة الحذا في الخبر الذي ذكرناه في الباب الذي قبل هذا من قول: إذا استكره الدم نقض وإن لم يستكره لم ينقض.

268 - 5 أحمد بن محمد بن عيسى عن الحسن بن علي بن بنت الياس قال: سمعته يقول:
رأيت أبي عليه السلام وقد رعف بعد ما توضأ دما سائلا فتوضأ.
فيحتمل وجوها، أحدها: أن تحمل على ضرب من التقية على ما قدمنا القول فيه والثاني:
أن نحملها على الاستحباب دون الوجوب والثالث: ان نحملها على غسل الموضع لان ذلك يسمى وضوءا على ما بيناه في كتاب " تهذيب الأحكام " ويدل على هذا المعنى:
269 - 6 - ما أخبرني به الشيخ رحمه الله عن أبي القاسم جعفر بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن محمد بن الحسين بن أبي الخطاب عن جعفر بن بشير عن أبي حبيب الأسدي عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال سمعته يقول: في الرجل يرعف وهو على وضوء قال: يغسل آثار الدم ويصلي.

Regarding a man afflicted with flowing blood? He said: "He performs ablution and repeats (the prayer)." He said: "And if it was not flowing, he performs ablution and continues (the prayer)." He said: "And he does that between al-Safa and al-Marwa."
268 - 5 Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Isa, from al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn the daughter of Ilyas, said: I heard him say:
"I saw my father, peace be upon him, bleeding from the nose after performing ablution, flowing blood, so he performed ablution."
This can be interpreted in several ways: First, to be understood as a form of dissimulation (taqiyya), as we have previously discussed. Second, to be understood as recommended (istihbab) rather than obligatory (wujub). Third, to be understood as washing the affected area, because that is called ablution, as we have explained in the book "Tahdhib al-Ahkam." Supporting this meaning is:
269 - 6 - What al-Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, narrated to me from Abu al-Qasim Jaafar ibn Muhammad, from his father, from Saad ibn Abdullah, from Muhammad ibn al-Hussein ibn Abi al-Khattab, from Jaafar ibn Bashir, from Abu Habib al-Asadi, from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: I heard him say: "Regarding a man who bleeds from the nose while he is in a state of ablution, he washes away the traces of blood and prays."
270 - 7 And from him, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from his father, from al-Hussein ibn al-Hasan ibn Aban, from al-Hussein ibn Saeed, from Uthman, from Sama'a, from Abu Basir, said: I heard him say: "If a man vomits while he is in a state of purity, he should rinse his mouth. And if he bleeds from the nose while he is in a state of ablution, he should wash his nose, for that is sufficient for him and he does not repeat his ablution." 51 - Chapter on Laughter and Loud Laughter.
271 - 1 Al-Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, narrated to me from Abu al-Qasim Jaafar ibn Muhammad, from Muhammad ibn Yaqub, from Muhammad ibn Ismail, from al-Fadl ibn Shadhan, from Safwan ibn Yahya, from Salim Abu al-Fadl (1).

text:
عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: ليس ينقض الوضوء الا ما خرج من طرفيك الأسفلين اللذين أنعم الله بهما عليك 272 - 2 عنه عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن الصفار عن أحمد بن محمد عن محمد بن سهل عن زكريا بن ادم قال: سألت الرضا عليه السلام عن الناصور (1) فقال: أنما ينقض الوضوء ثلاثة البول والغايط والريح.
273 - 3 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن أخيه الحسن عن زرعة عن سماعة قال:
سألته عما ينقض الوضوء قال: الحدث تسمع صوته أو تجد ريحه والقرقرة في البطن الا شيئا تصبر عليه والضحك في الصلاة والقيئ:
فالوجه في هذا الخبر أن نحمله على ضرب من الاستحباب أو على الضحك الذي لا يملك معه نفسه ولا يأمن أن يكون قد أحدث والذي يدل على ذلك:
274 - 4 ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن ابن أبي عمير عن رهط سمعوه يقول: إن التبسم في الصلاة لا ينقض الصلاة ولا ينقض الوضوء إنما يقطع الضحك الذي فيه القهقهة.
قوله: عليه السلام إنما يقطع الضحك الذي فيه القهقهة راجع إلى الصلاة دون الوضوء ألا ترى أنه قال: يقطع الضحك الذي فيه القهقهة والقطع لا يقال إلا في الصلاة لأنه لم تجر العادة أن يقال انقطع الوضوء وإنما يقال انقطعت الصلاة، ويحتمل أن يكون الخبران وردا مورد التقية لأنهما موافقان لمذاهب بعض العامة.
52 - باب انشاد الشعر 275 - 1 اخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن

He said: 'Only three things invalidate ablution: urine, feces, and wind.'"
273 - 3 As for what al-Hussein ibn Sa'id narrated from his brother al-Hasan, from Zur'a, from Sima'a, who said:
"I asked him about what invalidates ablution. He said: 'An event where you hear its sound or find its odor, and gurgling in the stomach except for something you endure, laughing in prayer, and vomiting.'"
The explanation for this report is that we should interpret it as a form of recommendation, or as laughing uncontrollably without being able to restrain oneself and being unsure if one has broken wind. That which indicates this is:
274 - 4 What al-Hussein ibn Sa'id narrated from Ibn Abi Umair, from a group who heard him say: "Smiling in prayer does not invalidate the prayer, nor does it invalidate ablution. It is only laughter with loud guffaws that interrupts."
His saying, peace be upon him, "It is only laughter with loud guffaws that interrupts," refers to the prayer, not ablution. Do you not see that he said: "interrupts laughter that contains loud guffaws," and interruption is only said in relation to prayer, because it is not customary to say "the ablution is interrupted," but rather "the prayer is interrupted." It is possible that the two reports were presented in a context of dissimulation (Taqiyya) because they agree with the doctrines of some of the common people.

أحمد بن محمد بن عيسى عن علي بن الحكم عن معاوية بن ميسرة قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن انشاد الشعر هل ينقض الوضوء؟ قال: لا 276 - 2 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن أخيه الحسن عن زرعه بن سماعة قال:
سألته عن نشد (1) الشعر هل ينقض الوضوء أو ظلم الرجل صاحبه أو الكذب؟
فقال: نعم إلا أن يكون شعرا يصدق فيه أو يكون يسيرا من الشعر الأبيات الثلاثة والأربعة فأما أن يكثر من الشعر الباطل فهو ينقض الوضوء.
فيحتمل الخبر وجهين: أحدهما أن يكون تصحف على الراوي فيكون قد روى بالصاد غير المعجمة دون الضاد المنقطة لان ذلك مما ينقص ثواب الوضوء، والثاني: أن يكون محمولا على الاستحباب 53 - باب القبلة ومس الفرج 277 - 1 اخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن سعد بن عبد الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن الحسين بن سعيد عن فضالة بن أيوب ومحمد بن أبي عمير عن جميل ابن دراج وحماد بن عثمان عن زرارة عن أبي جعفر عليه السلام قال: ليس في القبلة ولا في المباشرة ولا مس الفرج وضوء.
278 - 2 وبهذا الاسناد عن الحسين بن سعيد عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبان بن عثمان عن أبي مريم قال: قلت لأبي جعفر عليه السلام ما تقول في الرجل يتوضأ ثم يدعو جاريته فتأخذ بيده حتى ينتهي إلى المسجد فإن من عندنا يزعمون أنها الملامسة؟ فقال: لا والله

فهذا الخبر لا يعارض ما قدمناه من الاخبار لأنه خبر واحد وقد تضمن من قصة أمير المؤمنين عليه السلام وأمره المقداد بمسألة النبي صلى الله عليه وآله وجوابه له ما ينافي المعروف في هذه القصة، وهو الذي تضمنته رواية إسحاق بن عمار، وانه حين سأله قال: له ليس بشئ، على أنه يحتمل أن يكون الراوي قد ترك بعض الخبر لان محمد بن إسماعيل راوي هذا الخبر روى هذه القصة بعينها فإنه قال أمرني بإعادة الوضوء، قلت له فإن لم أتوضأ قال: لا بأس.

302 - 12 As for what Al-Hasan ibn Mahbub narrated from Ibn Sinan from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "Three things exit from the urethra: semen, which requires ghusl (ritual bath); wadi, which requires wudu (ablution) because it exits from the trickles of urine." He said, "And madhi does not require wudu; it is only like what exits from the nose."
His saying, peace be upon him, "wadi, which requires wudu" is to be understood as meaning that if one has not performed istibra (cleansing after urination) as we mentioned, and something exits after that, then it is obligatory to repeat the wudu because it will be from the remnants of urine. He indicated this by saying: "because it exits from the trickles of urine," an indication that it is either urine or mixed with urine. And what clarifies what we mentioned is:
303 - 13 What Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated from Yaqub ibn Yazid from Ibn Abi Umayr from Jamil ibn Salih from Abd al-Malik ibn Amr from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a man who urinates, then cleanses himself, then finds wetness after that, he said: "If he urinates, then pulls what is between the anus and the testicles three times, and presses what is between them, then cleanses himself, and then it flows even reaching the market (1), then he should not worry." And what increases that in clarity is:
304 - 14 What Al-Hussein ibn Saeed narrated from Hammad from Hurayz from someone who informed him from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "Wadhi does not invalidate wudu; it is only like mucus and spittle."
205 - 15 From him, from Hammad from Hurayz, who said: Zayd al-Shahham, Zurara, and Muhammad ibn Muslim narrated to me from Abi Abdullah, peace be upon him, that he said: "If something flows from your penis, whether madhi or wadhi, then do not wash it, do not interrupt the prayer for it, and do not invalidate the wudu for it; it is only like phlegm. 306 - 16 As for what Al-Hussein bin Saeed narrated from Ibn Abi Umair, who said: Yaqub bin Yaqteen narrated to me, saying: I asked Abu al-Hasan, peace be upon him, about a man who emits prostatic fluid (madhy) while praying, whether due to desire or not due to desire? He said: "Ablution (Wudu) is required from prostatic fluid."
His saying, peace be upon him, "Ablution is required from prostatic fluid" can be interpreted as astonishment at it. As if, due to its fame and obviousness in not repeating ablution from it, he said: "This is something that requires ablution." It can also be interpreted as a form of dissimulation (taqiyya) because that is the opinion of most of the common people (Sunnis).
57 - Chapter on Touching Iron 307 - 1 The Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, informed me from Abu al-Qasim Jaafar bin Muhammad from Muhammad bin Yaqub from Muhammad bin Ismail from al-Fadl bin Shadhan from Safwan from Ibn Miskan from Muhammad al-Halabi who said: I asked Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, about a man who is in a state of purity (Tohr) and trims his nails or hair, does he need to repeat ablution? He said: "No, but he should wipe his head and nails with water." He said: I said, "They claim that it requires ablution." He said: "If they argue with you, do not argue with them, and say: This is the Sunnah."
308 - 2 Al-Hussein bin Saeed from Hammad bin Issa from Hurayz from Zurara who said: I said to Abu Jaafar, peace be upon him: A man trims his nails, cuts his mustache, and takes from the hair of his head and beard, does that invalidate his ablution? He said: "O Zurara, all of this is Sunnah, and ablution is an obligation (Faridah), and nothing from the Sunnah invalidates the obligation, and indeed that increases his purity."
309 - 3 Saad from Ayyub bin Noah from Safwan bin Yahya from Saeed bin Abdullah al-Araj who said: I said to Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him: I take from my nails and from my mustache and shave my head.

Sa'id from Musaddaq bin Sadaqa from 'Ammar "bin Musa" (1) al-Sabbati who said: I asked Abu Abdullah about a man who performed ablution (wudu), then ate meat or ghee; is he allowed to pray without washing his hand? He said: Yes, but if it was milk, he should not pray until he washes his hand and rinses his mouth. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, would pray after eating meat without washing his hand, but if it was milk, he would not pray until he washed his hand and rinsed his mouth.
The implication of this narration to wash the hands, rinse the mouth, and sniff water into the nose for someone who drank milk is to be interpreted as recommended, not obligatory, based on the first narration.
Books on Obligatory and Recommended Ablutions 59 - Chapter on the Obligation of Ghusl (Ritual Bath) for Janabah (State of Impurity after Sexual Activity), Menstruation, Istihadha (Non-Menstrual Bleeding), Nifas (Postpartum Bleeding), and Touching the Dead 314 - 1 The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, informed me from Ahmad bin Muhammad from his father from Sa'd bin Abdullah from Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Isa from Ali bin al-Hakam from Saif bin 'Amira from Abu Bakr who said:
I asked Abu Ja'far, peace be upon him, how should I do if I am in a state of Janabah (2)? He said: Wash your palms (3) and your private parts, perform ablution like the ablution for prayer, then perform ghusl.
315 - 2 From him, from Ahmad bin Muhammad from his father from Muhammad bin Yahya from Muhammad bin Ali bin Mahbub from Ahmad bin Muhammad from al-Hussein bin Sa'id from Uthman bin Isa from Sama'a who said: Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, said: Ghusl for Janabah is obligatory, and ghusl for a menstruating woman when she becomes pure is obligatory, and ghusl for a woman experiencing Istihadha is obligatory if she plugs herself with cotton and the blood passes the cotton, then she must perform ghusl for every two prayers and ghusl for Fajr prayer. But if the blood does not pass the cotton, then she must perform ghusl once every day and ablution.

ابن محمد عن سعد بن أبي خلف قال: سمعت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام يقول: الغسل في أربعة عشر موطنا، واحد فريضة والباقي سنة.
فالمعنى فيه ان واحدا منها فريضة بظاهر القرآن وإن كانت هناك أغسال اخر يعلم فرضها بالسنة 320 - 7 فاما ما رواه سعد بن عبد الله عن علي بن خالد عن محمد بن الوليد عن حماد بن عثمان عن معاوية بن عمار عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: سمعته يقول ليس على النفساء غسل في السفر.
فالوجه فيه انه ليس عليها غسل إذا لم تتمكن من استعمال الماء إما لتعذره أو لحاجتها إليه أو مخافة البرد وليس المراد انه ليس عليها غسل على كل حال.
60 - باب وجوب غسل الميت وغسل من مس ميتا 321 - 1 أخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أبي القاسم جعفر بن محمد عن محمد بن يعقوب عن علي بن إبراهيم عن أبيه عن حماد بن عيسى عن حريز عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: من غسل ميتا فليغتسل قلت: فأن مسه ما دام حارا؟ قال: فلا غسل عليه، وإذا برد ثم مسه فليغتسل، قلت: على من ادخله القبر؟ قال: لا غسل عليه إنما يمس الثياب.
322 - 2 وبهذا الاسناد عن محمد بن يعقوب عن عدة من أصحابنا عن سهل بن زياد عن أحمد بن محمد بن أبي نصر عن عبد الله بن سنان عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: يغتسل الذي غسل الميت، وان قبل الميت إنسان بعد موته وهو حار فليس عليه غسل، ولكن إذا مسه وقبله وقد برد فعليه الغسل ولا بأس ان يمسه بعد الغسل ويقبله.
323 - 3 أخبرني الشيخ رحمه الله عن أحمد بن محمد عن أبيه عن الصفار عن محمد بن عيسى

Ibn Muhammad from Sa'd ibn Abi Khalaf who said: I heard Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, say: "The ghusl (ritual bath) is required in fourteen instances; one is obligatory, and the rest are recommended."
The meaning is that one of them is obligatory based on the apparent meaning of the Quran, even if there are other ghusls whose obligation is known through the Sunnah. 320 - 7 As for what Sa'd ibn Abdullah narrated from Ali ibn Khalid from Muhammad ibn al-Walid from Hammad ibn Uthman from Muawiyah ibn Ammar from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "I heard him say: 'A woman in post-partum bleeding (Nufasaa) does not have to perform ghusl while traveling.'"
The reason for this is that she does not have to perform ghusl if she cannot use water, either because it is unavailable, or she needs it for something else, or she fears the cold. It does not mean that she never has to perform ghusl in any situation.
60 - Chapter on the Obligation of Ghusl for the Deceased and Ghusl for One Who Touches a Deceased Person 321 - 1 The Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, informed me from Abu al-Qasim Jaafar ibn Muhammad from Muhammad ibn Yaqub from Ali ibn Ibrahim from his father from Hammad ibn Isa from Hurayz from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "Whoever washes a deceased person should perform ghusl." I said: "What if he touches him while he is still warm?" He said: "Then there is no ghusl upon him. But if he touches him after he has become cold, then he should perform ghusl." I said: "What about the one who puts him in the grave?" He said: "There is no ghusl upon him; he is only touching the clothes."
322 - 2 And with this same chain of narration, from Muhammad ibn Yaqub from several of our companions from Sahl ibn Ziyad from Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Nasr from Abdullah ibn Sinan from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him, who said: "The one who washes the deceased performs ghusl. And if a person kisses the deceased after his death while he is still warm, then there is no ghusl upon him. But if he touches him and kisses him after he has become cold, then ghusl is required. And there is no problem in touching him and kissing him after the ghusl."
323 - 3 The Sheikh, may God have mercy on him, informed me from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from his father from al-Saffar from Muhammad ibn Isa

text:
عن القاسم الصيقل قال: كتبت إليه جعلت فداك هل إغتسل أمير المؤمنين عليه السلام حين غسل رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله عند موته؟ فاجابه: النبي صلى الله عليه وآله طاهر مطهر ولكن أمير المؤمنين عليه السلام فعل وجرت به السنة.
324 - 4 الحسين بن سعيد عن النضر بن سويد عن عاصم بن حميد قال: سألته عن الميت إذا مسه الانسان أفيه غسل (1) قال: فقال: إذا مسست جسده حين يبرد فاغتسل.
325 - 5 سعد بن عبد الله عن أيوب بن نوح عن بعض أصحابنا عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: إذا قطع من الرجل قطعة. فهي ميتة فإذا مسه الانسان فكل ما كان فيه عظم فقد وجب على من يمسه الغسل، فإن لم يكن فيه عظم فلا غسل عليه.
326 - 6 فأما ما رواه الحسين بن سعيد عن محمد بن أبي عمير عن جميل بن دراج عن محمد ابن مسلم عن أبي جعفر عليه السلام قال: مس الميت عند موته وبعد غسله والقبلة ليس به بأس.
327 - 7 عنه عن فضاله عن السكوني عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام قال: ان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله قبل عثمان بن مظعون بعد موته.
فالوجه في هذين الخبرين أن نحملهما على أن التقبيل إذا كان بعد الموت قبل ان يبرد أو بعد الغسل لم يجب فيه الغسل على ما بيناه في خبر عبد الله بن سنان وذلك مفصل، وهذان الخبران مجملان والحكم بالمفصل أولى منه بالمجمل ولا ينافي ذلك:
328 - 8 ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن أحمد بن الحسن عن عمرو بن سعيد عن مصدق

From al-Qasim al-Sayqal who said: I wrote to him, may I be made your ransom, did Amir al-Mu'minin, peace be upon him, perform ghusl when he washed the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, at his death? He replied: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is pure and purified, but Amir al-Mu'minin, peace be upon him, did it, and the Sunnah was established by it.
324 - 4 Al-Husayn ibn Sa'id from al-Nadr ibn Suwayd from 'Asim ibn Humayd who said: I asked him about a dead person if a person touches him, does it require ghusl? He said: If you touch his body when it becomes cold, then perform ghusl.
325 - 5 Sa'd ibn 'Abd Allah from Ayyub ibn Nuh from some of our companions from Abi 'Abd Allah, peace be upon him, who said: If a piece is cut off from a man, it is considered dead flesh. If a person touches it, then everything in which there is bone requires ghusl for whoever touches it, but if there is no bone in it, then there is no ghusl upon him.
326 - 6 As for what al-Husayn ibn Sa'id narrated from Muhammad ibn Abi 'Umayr from Jamil ibn Darraj from Muhammad ibn Muslim from Abi Ja'far, peace be upon him, who said: Touching the dead person at his death and after washing him, and kissing him, there is nothing wrong with that.
327 - 7 From him, from Fadala from al-Sakuni from Abi 'Abd Allah, peace be upon him, who said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, kissed 'Uthman ibn Maz'un after his death.
The explanation of these two reports is that we interpret them to mean that if the kissing is after death before it cools down, or after washing, ghusl is not required, as we explained in the report of 'Abd Allah ibn Sinan, and that is detailed, and these two reports are brief. The ruling with the detailed is more appropriate than with the brief, and that does not contradict:
328 - 8 What Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated from Ahmad ibn al-Hasan from 'Amr ibn Sa'id from Musaddiq
